newsitem.title: EGYPT: Egypt to maintain cotton price for farmers.
newsitem.headline: Egypt to maintain cotton price for farmers.

text.p: The Egyptian government will pay farmers 500 pounds a qantar (10 pounds a kg or about 134 centilibres) for their cotton this year, government newspapers said on Friday, quoting Agriculture Minister Youssef Wali.
The minimum producer price last year was also 500 pounds -- an amount which helped push production up to 360,000 tonnes but also kept private-sector traders out of the cotton market.
At this price, which is slightly higher than average world prices, the government ended up subsidising the farmers and the private sector could not compete.
Wali said the agricultural credit bank had set aside two billion pounds to buy the cotton crop. That amount would buy up to 200,000 tonnes.
Earlier this week a government newspaper said Egypt would increase the area to be planted with cotton by 100,000 acres to one million acres this growing season, which starts in February.
The area is forecast to produce 400,000 tonnes of cotton, the government daily al-Ahram said.
